summary:
Three shots ring out.

Steve hears them before he feels them; a warm, wet pain burning in his torso, intolerably excruciating.

There’s a bundle of squawks and screams, outbursts of panic and anger, and it’s only when Hopper falls forwards to take Steve up into a slightly rough, protective hold, does he realize that two of those shots have lodged themselves in his own flesh and bone. (Realizes that he’d moved, instinctively, to shield El, despite never having spoken to her, who’d the gun had been so precisely pointed at, aimed for.)

text:
“I can’t believe I just watched you lose so  disastrously to a bunch of fifteen year olds,” 




Comes Robin’s voice from the backseat, piping up after a calm moment of silence where Steve  wasn’t  being tormented in his own car. A little handful of giggles follow, Dustin, Max, Lucas and  Eddie, all deviously chuckling away at his transgressions. 




“Yeah, yeah, laugh it up. It’s not like I’m wasting all my gas driving you guys back home later,” Steve tosses a glare over his shoulder, shutting up only Lucas, who gives him a little polite smile, still twinged with mischief. 




Eddie grins, rugged and effortlessly attractive in a way that has his stomach turning. “No, she’s right, Stevie, who knew bowling was your weakness?”




“Maybe I was just letting Will win. It’s his birthday, asshole,” 




“Bullllllshit! Will didn’t even  win,  Max did!” Dustin protests from his place in the front seat, pointing accusingly. “You put the ball in the gutter  every time!”




“Pipe down, dipshit, you’re distracting me, the driver, remember? Driving you guys around?” Steve scolds, scowling off into space, taking a slightly more aggressive turn than necessary. 




Will’s birthday was a pretty big affair, a warm day in May just as they all recovered from the fight against Vecna. They’d just stopped the fourth gate from opening by the skin of their teeth—Hopper’s government friends arriving just in time to stop Jason from helping Vecna kill Max by proxy, leaving her with just the  one broken arm. 




Eddie had got out of the Hawkin’s Lab hospital pretty recently, after Steve had lugged his sorry half-corpse through the portal in the weak hope that they could do  something— and they did. His heart stopped a few too many times and now they were worried about long term complications, or something, some new technology called a heart monitor—but right now he was lax, leaned back and grinning in the backseat of his car, continuously catching his eye in the rear view mirror.




Steve had a gnarly scar, raised and angry across his throat, one that looked like someone had tried to slit it, or something—but Eddie had said it was pretty sick. Plus, it was a contributor to why they’d been stuck in the hospital together for a couple weeks. Turns out the bats  did have rabies, sort of—at least some kind of sickness, like the flu, or the plague, as Robin had said. 




(It was pretty cool having matching scars with Eddie where the bats had taken huge chunks out of their torsos, but no normal person would ever fucking say that, so Steve kept that one to himself.)




So now they were on the way to some corny, kiddy pizza place, one of the new ones with animal robot mascots and shit, but more excitingly—an arcade. Pizza, plus arcade? Happy kids. Very, very happy kids. 




Happy kids who were very excited to get there, who slammed the doors of his car on their way out even as he grumbled in warning to  not do that, ignoring him entirely as they reunited with the other cars in the lot. 




Joyce had hitched a ride in Hopper’s new station wagon, Will, El and Mike all stuffed in the back, Jonathan and Nancy pulling up shortly afterwards, ABBA blaring out of the car speakers as they did. 




And it was nice, he thought, sunglasses slightly askew on his face as he tilted his head up to enjoy the sun, the corners of his eyes crinkling as he took a deep breath in, preparing himself for hyper, angsty teens and the greasy power of pizza. 




Then comes a hand on the small of his back—Eddie, friendly, touchy Eddie, who shoots him a smile before chasing on after Dustin. 




Steve swallows, trying not to think about the gesture  too hard, before setting off, lagging behind the group a little as a result. And it’s strangely nice, comforting, sort of, watching them all from behind, watching the way they move together, a small, friendly army. Studying the way they’ve healed, grown older, grown together.
 
Then he realizes it’s sort of creepy, and starts jogging to keep up—when he notices the bracelet.
 
El’s bracelet. The little blue one she’s had on her wrist for a while. It’s fallen just a little way from where she’s walking now, just ahead of Steve. 
 
Crouching down, he scoops it up—calling out to her. There’s a pause where she turns back and looks a tad baffled, because it’s not like her and Steve have ever  spoken, really, but they’ve meshed together in the midst of alternate dimension battle, and that’s always sort of been enough.
 
He wiggles the bracelet in the air, smiling at her warmly, growing into a grin when her face lights up in recognition, and she jogs a little awkwardly over to his beckoning. 
 
But it’s when he turns, just at a slightly different angle, adjusting to be able to give it to her, does he see something in the corner of his eye, just behind them. A shift, a form, a man. 
 
It only takes a glance, an inch of movement for Steve to see  something  thrown, or  drawn  aggressively upwards in the direction of the approaching Eleven, who’s yet to notice. Nobody else  has noticed. 
 
Just Steve. 
 
Steve, who grabs Eleven and tosses the two of them in a completely different direction, a choked apology tumbling out of his mouth as he knocks her to the floor hard enough to leave a nasty bruise. He’s not really sure if he even managed to get it out before he’s standing over her, staring down at the sheer terror and confusion that marks her like a deer in headlights. 







Three shots ring out.
 
Steve hears them before he feels them; a warm, wet pain burning in his torso, intolerably excruciating. 
 
There’s a bundle of squawks and screams, outbursts of panic and anger, and it’s only when Hopper falls forwards to take Steve up into a slightly rough, protective hold, does he realize that two of those shots have lodged themselves in his own flesh and bone. (Realizes that he’d moved, instinctively, to shield El, despite never having spoken to her, who’d the gun had been so precisely pointed at, aimed for.)
 
Steve Harrington watches his own blood pool and trickle over a series of hands pressed against him, small and large, soft and rugged, and for a moment, wants to stay like this. He can’t. 




Because then Joyce is running for a phone, and Jonathan has Will pressed against him as if he expects another round, another gun; perhaps a relic of their time in California, something Steve had always meant to ask about but never managed to. Nancy is trying to wrangle Max, who’s shouting and fighting to get away—get to  him, he realizes, vaguely, while Robin pushes past them to do just that, her shaking hands trying to soothe him, one on his face while the other braces her body against the concrete of the pavement he’s begun to bleed out on. 




The kids—he thinks, in a fleeting moment of panic—only to find them all, crowding the gaggle of limbs he’s become, listless and entirely out of his control. Their hands pressed hard enough to scald, so when Steve choked on his own startled sob; he blamed it partly on the pain, another on the mere idea that these kids even know what to do when someone they know is shot in broad daylight. 




Lucas is looking wildly back and forth between Steve and Max, as if trying to choose who to try and comfort, and Steve wills the dead weight of his tongue to move, to tell him to go to her; any attempt is shushed by Mike, who looks furious. It’s a familiar expression—identical to Nancy’s anger, all contained to the small downward curve of their lip, stuffed into that compact countenance when they know it’s not the time or place to let it run free. 




Then there’s Dustin, who’s causing the most trouble for Hopper, practically on top of Steve, periodically shaking him back and forth by the shoulders. He only gets a handful of the constant stream of heartbroken shrieking that comes tumbling from his mouth, a collection of “Don’t do this to me Steve,”s and “Stay awake, you can’t do this,”s, “You can’t do this to me,”s. Tears streaming down round cheeks, one disrupted by a broken handprint of already-drying blood, probably from the one he can no longer feel. 




Steve doesn’t remember touching Dustin’s face, searches for it in the occasional blackouts he keeps falling victim to; supposing that it’s just second nature, at this point. To try and comfort him first. But the more he tastes the bitter bile in the back of his throat, the metallic taste of blood in his mouth, trickling down his chin, does that become more difficult to do. 




(He wonders, briefly, if this is how Eddie felt. The sickening, feverish guilt of making the kid who practically worships you sob about your possible, impending, looking pretty likely death.)




 Then Steve gets to thinking about Eddie, searches for him, in the gaggle of his terrified onlookers, and finds him, uncharacteristically silent with sheer anguish as he hovers, too scared to get too close. For all of the hands pressed to Steve, big and small, he longs, for a second, for the limp, ring-clad fist at Eddie’s side to grasp at him too, and finds himself too far gone to speculate about why that might be. 




Maybe he asked, though, he’s not sure he can speak at all—or maybe the look in his eyes was pleading enough; pathetic enough. Because as soon as Eddie chances a glance in his direction, he’s collapsing to his knees by Steve’s side, taking his wrist between two rough palms, lacing their fingers together until the cool metal of his rings has a bloody chuckle oozing out of his mouth. 




It hurts to do, sets a fire of wet, fresh agony alight in his chest, but he wins, really. Eddie meets his eyes, a melancholy fondness growing in them, pooling in the form of tears at their corners, and smiles at him crookedly, setting one of his hands against Steve’s face, thumb brushing beneath one of his eyes. “Cmon, man. You’ve got this.” 




Steve’s not sure what he’s got, but if it has Eddie looking at him like that, it must be pretty great. 




“You’re Steve  Harrington.  You’re—the most metal guy I know. Bat-wielding, bat-fucking-teeth-shredding  maniac. ” Steve’s not really sure what Eddie’s saying, but that’s comforting in a sense, because Steve isn’t really ever sure what Eddie’s trying to say. 




“He’s right,” Comes the bubbling, anxious addition from Robin, who’s lap is cushioning his head, sharing the weight of his enervated body with Hopper. “You’re—you’ve, we’ve, survived  way  , way-way-way-  way  worse than this, Steve, you can’t—it’s. It’s just a couple bullets. It’s—it’s not so bad. You’re gonna be totally fine, cuz if you aren’t, I’m gonna have to pick up your shifts at work too, and that’s gonna totally blow, because, well, think of all—all the babes you’ll miss, and I’ll—I’ll have to organize the tapes according to, to  my  recommendations, and you—you know my movie choices totally suck, you can’t,” She draws in a gasp of air, chest heaving. “You have to be there, you know—you know I’m totally useless under the crushing pressure of responsibility, Steve, I’ll totally get us both fired and I’ll feel  so, so bad,” 




If she wasn’t already crying, she was now, a steady stream of sobs wracking her jittering form as she leaned over him, panicked babbles now just whimpers and cries. Maybe that’s what breaks the real headline to Steve, the breaking news of,  you’re going to die this time.  




Because Nancy pulls Robin away from him, gathering her into her fierce arms and holding the girl with such a force that it sets Steve’s head spinning—wondering if they had really become that close after Vecna, or if Steve was really, really screwed. It starts to feel like the latter, because then he finds Max at his feet, cradled by Lucas as she grips his shins and cusses him out, and she’s bawling, too. It makes him uneasy; Max hadn’t cried in front of Steve since they’d caught her, saved her from Vecna’s curse at the foot of Billy’s grave—that thought brought a crushing revelation to the drowning attentiveness he had left.




Maybe that’s what this all reminds her of. That’s what Steve is doing to her, here, forcing her to relive that again. He feels sick, his own blood spilling out over his own lips, watching Dustin and Max sobbing over him as his actions force them to experience some of their worst trauma all over again.




That’s what finally gets him talking again, picking up his tongue from where it lay, dead, in his mouth, dragging it to form the panicked prattle of apologies that he can’t stop once they start; a sorry for Hopper, who he’s collapsed against, bleeding all over, Joyce, who’s shouting at onlookers hysterically, desperate to help him, Robin, who’s not even trying to hide how she feels this situation is going to go, having a full-blown panic attack in Nancy’s arms, who he apologizes to, too, for everything, past and present, to Jonathan, who’s resembling a kicked puppy, the way that had Steve hesitate in feeling resentment for him all those years ago, now just turning a fresh blanket of guilt in his gut, for Will, who’s birthday he’s just absolutely fucking ruined, Mike, for never quite understanding him as much as the other kids, for dying to save his super-powered girlfriend, Dustin, for giving him the rapport of fatherly, brotherly support he’d so desperately needed only to rob away from him now, Lucas, for forever forcing him to join him in being the more mature one of the kids, for leaving him in the Creel House to get near beat to death by Jason while he was out of reach in the upside down, Max, for usurping Billy as her brother, only to leave her in the same way, leaving her more vulnerable to Vecna, should he ever return, to Eddie, for every King-Steve lookalike who’s ever called him shit that makes his stomach turn to hear now, for every member of the godforsaken town who still graffitis his trailer, still throws things at him on the streets despite the Hawkin’s Lab fantastic, government pardon they’d donned as soon as the situation was ‘contained,’ and for not having enough energy to understand why he’d liked wearing his vest jacket so much, or why he’s so needily searching his eyes for the answer now, the light around his vision beginning to fade. 




And to El. For forcing her to experience someone else dying in her stead, for putting the weight of his life on her shoulders along with the rest of the world, for layering a fresh coating of blood on her hands, giving her another nightmare to live with forever. 




That last apology has Hopper grip him tighter, suddenly, as if he’d decided that Steve couldn’t do that, couldn’t damage his daughter even more than his previous failures already had. Large arms scoop under his, searing, white hot pain climbing him in vines and branches as the newly-reinstated police chief begins bodily dragging him across the pavement towards the small gathering of cars parked at the roadside, ignoring the screams that rub his throat raw, the pain so bad it sinks him into the suffocating darkness of near-unconsciousness multiple times. 




The next time his vision returns, he’s splayed across the backseat of a car he doesn’t recognize, and his words are so heavy in his mouth he can’t shift his tongue to speak. This doesn’t stop him from trying, only to find a hand cradling his face, shushing him. They smell vaguely of flowery perfume and the confusing addition of a faint, cheap men’s cologne. Had he been in a better state of mind, he probably could’ve played the gentle, motherly touches as Joyce—unfortunately, he wasn’t, and instead what came was a strained, pitiful little wheeze. 




“Mom?” To be fair to himself, he couldn’t really see, or feel, past the pain—but he felt her stiffen beneath the limp strength of his neck. 




A gruff voice is muttering away in the front seat, and part of Steve is sure he can recognize the tone, the vague outline of the body even as it swerves and jolts. Driving with such a force that the three people in the back cradling Steve keep holding too tight, choking a wailing scream out of him, deliriously thrashing with as much force as he can muster before a colorful harmony of strained voices pull him back into place, before he inevitably falls back into the cool darkness of before.








 There’s Hopper, screaming at Dustin, who’s in the front seat and keeps screaming at  him,  fearless in the face of Steve’s fickle chances of survival as they hurtle their way towards the hospital, having decided the ambulance wouldn’t get to them in time. Now reaching the sixth minute since the undercover American government agent pulled a gun and shot two rounds into Steve before Hopper returned the favor, blowing his brains out on the sun-warmed pavements of Hawkin’s central town plaza, they were swiftly running out of time. The sentiment was all the more urgent whenever Robin would cry out that Steve had fallen asleep again and  wouldn’t wake up, Hopper instructing Eddie, sat between Joyce and Robin with his hands pushing down on Steve’s bleeding torso, to push down harder, use the pain to wake him up again. 




Every blood-curdling scream that came out of the guy’s mouth brought bile to the back of Eddie’s throat, the dry feeling of Steve’s flaking blood between his fingers mingling with the fresh, wet, thick renewal of it from the wounds he’s trying and failing to keep enough pressure on almost enough to have him faint himself. The only things keeping  him  awake is the distressed shrieking of Dustin in the front seat, the white knuckles of Robin, whose fingers are digging into his arm hard enough to draw blood, the firm trust of Hopper and the fear of his disapproval, for he’d pointed at him, hand bloody from Steve’s paling body, and said, “  You, Munson, come with us, now,”  




He was the chosen one, in all of this. Robin was Steve’s soulmate, in a sense, she could never leave him and fled Nancy’s embrace to do just that. Dustin was similar, though at first Hopper protested, they had no time for arguments, the boy throwing himself into the shotgun of the “borrowed” civilian truck. 
Joyce—he hardly knew the woman, outside of the warm hug she’d given him that one time when he’d given Will a lift home as a new member of Hellfire (Rebranded to Demobat’s Dungeon to avoid persecution) and thanked him, for letting Will play, for being kind to him, as if he  wouldn’t be. She was cradling Steve’s upper body now, uncaring for the blood and gore he shed over her clothes, something he thought impossible for a middle aged mother, who, in his imagination, were all about hating stains and keeping things pristine. 




Which is probably why the faces of his fellow passengers looked so grim when Steve spoke up through his spotty wakefulness to ask after her as if she truly was his mother—a sign that they were on the brink of losing him for good. 




Steve’s eyes were rolling back into his skull until all Eddie could see were the whites of them, not the deep, chocolate-brown, puppy-like gaze he was so used to pining after, seeking, and all he could think of was Chrissy, the thud of her body on his floor, the weight of her in his arms when she refused to wake up. 




“ Steve.  Steve, man, you gotta stay awake for me,” He pushes his hands down into the blood again, cringing at the feeling of the raw flesh, but when it doesn’t earn him a heart-wrenching cry from the boy splayed across his lap, he falters, going cold all over. “Steve. Steve?  Steve!”  




Casting a hand over his face, Eddie grips him by the chin, trying to rouse some kind of signs of life while Dustin’s crying hikes back up again in the front seat, Robin spewing panicked rambles about what he should and shouldn’t do to wake him, Joyce and Hopper shouting over each other from the opposite ends of the car.




Eddie slaps him, then, though he doesn’t really remember doing it, just the burning aftertaste of guilt when those eyes flutter open again, drowning in confusion as they lull up to stare at him. “There we go, that’s it, pretty boy, keep those eyes on me, you got it? Let’s not sleep just yet, Stevie,” He casts one hand through his hair, stroking the side of his face, Joyce mirroring his actions a little more delicately. 




Steve just looks entirely too confused for it to be fair, in this situation, the situation  he  put himself in, in the line of fire, like a hero,  again—  but then he starts humming, and Eddie’s throat goes dry, not needing to warn the driver that they were running out of time, running out of  Steve,  and any sense he ever had  left.  




But then he listens, just a little, amongst the sounds of anguish, at the gentle, rasping tune Steve hums to him, cold, limp hand doing its best to grip the front of his shirt. 





 Hmm, hmm hmmm hmmm. Hmm-hhm hrmm hmm hmmmm. 





“Oh my god,” And Eddie laughs, then, because Steve had been complaining about missing  the most metal concert ever,  as described by Dustin, and Eddie had fulfilled his promise to play it for him just the other day, a little stoned, a little drunk on his full attention. And now Steve was bleeding out in his lap, trying his very best to hum Metallica’s  Master of the Puppets  to him as he died. 




“Eddie,” Steve’s hand flops weakly, an invitation, one he takes readily, looking at a worried Robin briefly before returning his full attention to the man of the hour. “Ed.  Ed— ” 




His throat feels like sandpaper. “Save your strength, Stevie boy, you’re not looking so hot right now,” 




“That’s—well that’s, that’s rude,” Comes the bloody giggle, lips and teeth stained with it as he chokes out any quip he can muster. “You don’t think I’m—pretty, Ed? I thought I was,  pretty boy, to—to you,” 




Something settles in his gut, a warmth, yet also a dread. “Come on Stevie, don’t do this to me right now,” He casts another bloody hand through his hair, inexplicably fond. 




“Sorry,” It’s so  earnest,  it hurts, and it has Robin shout at Hopper to go  faster.  




 “Hey,” Eddie jostles him a little. “We already heard your apologies, Stevie, I don’t think we can take any more.”




Joyce nods silently in agreement, giving Steve’s hand a little squeeze. 




“But—your jacket. Ed, Eddie, you, I need to,” He coughs, a handful of blood spilling out of his mouth, down his chin and neck, eyes rolling back again. “It’s, I—folded. In my, table, by—by my bed. I’m sorry, I didn’t get it,” Another wet cough. “Back to you. I meant to.”




He doesn’t know he’s crying until he feels wet hot tears running over the slightly lopsided bridge of his nose, sniffling a little as he gives Steve another gentle slap to the cheek. “Hey now. It suits you, Stevie. I thought I told you to keep that thing?” 




But he’s gone, lulling back into the intoxicating draught of the unconscious, the whites of his eyes twitching uncomfortably through thick, damp eyelashes, before Robin takes her turn, hitting Steve in a frustrated move of pure distress, gripping his face with both hands, determined. 




“Rob?” Steve’s eyes bounce up and down and back, misty and milky and far too distant to be right. “Robin, we gotta—we’re gonna be sooo,” He hiccups. “So, so late for work, Rob, it’s—it’s okay. I’ll tell…! Keith,  Keith, I’ll tell ‘im I… forgot, that I have a car, ‘n he’ll just ‘ave’a go, ‘t me,” 




“ Steve,” Robin weeps, bitterly, pressing a firm kiss to his forehead, one of her tears beginning to roll down his face from where it had dropped from her. 




He goes again, for longer this time, pale enough and breathing so shallow that Eddie was sure, for just a moment that he’d died, dedicating his last words to  Keith, of all people—but after Joyce had cried out to Hopper and he cut a corner hard enough to climb the curb, Steve had startled awake again, eyelids heavy and pupils blown wide. 




“Dustin, I—I gotta, find Dustin,” His eyes don’t fix on anyone, voice feebly begging to anyone listening. “M’s ‘Ender’sson, she ge’s so, so  worried,  s’mmhm, givin’ mhm a liff’’ome, ‘ome where’s… where’s my  kid, I can’—I can’ fin’d’im,” 




Steve’s sobbing, tears mixing with blood, staining his supple face with tracks of agony. “I can’ t find’m,”




One of his hands grips Eddie’s hard enough to bruise. “Y’gotta—y’gggh. Y’ggh,” And he looks up to meet eyes with Dustin, who’s abandoned his front seat, climbing as much as he can into the back to reach for Steve, reach for  Eddie,  crying hard enough that he can feel it in his  chest, a deep, primal reaction.




“ Steve,”  Dustin eventually manages, leaning over the seat to hold his head, tilt it his way. But Steve looks past him, at first, eyes distant and foggy.  “Steve!”  




There’s just a second, a fleeting moment, a final one—where those deep, beautiful eyes clear, just long enough to see Dustin. A gentle, fond smile stretches across his face, barely there, as Steve uses the last of his strength to drag his hand over where Dustin’s rests, over his heart, and threads one or two of their fingers together. 




Just a second. 




Because Eddie watches, firsthand, as despondent horror grows on Dustin’s face. He feels the last of Steve’s body go limp, head falling back into his lap. 





Feels as the last of his life leaves him, stretched out across them like a martyr. 

The next time Steve opens his eyes, he’s younger. Everything is, really—his house, carpets softer than the hardwood floors in the foyer now, walls still the gently peach colour they were when he was a kid, reminiscent of the warmer colours of the seventies. There’s a picture hanging there, one that no longer does so—it’s a family portrait, when getting those taken was the trend of the week in Hawkin’s suburbia. 





Steve can see his murky reflection in the glass of the frame before he looks through it—and fleetingly, he knows he must be about seven, about 

miserable, 

the hand of his father gripping his shoulder just a little too firmly. If he tries, he can still remember the light purple indents, the bruises, left from posing for that stupid, ugly picture, remembers being nine, watching his mother use it as ammunition the third or fourth time Harrington Senior was caught having an affair on a ‘business trip.’ 





That’d been when they’d begun to go together every time, after that argument, when nobody had picked up the broken glass from the picture frame and Steve had stayed quiet about the piece he’d accidentally stepped on, the piece he’d pulled out of the flesh of his foot like a ribbon from a gift, bleeding all over the pristine tiles of his en-suite bathroom. When his mother wanted to be certain, at least, that his father was sleeping with a prostitute in the motel room next door. It was less humiliating for her, in that way. 





But where Steve is now, the portrait still hangs. So Steve must be seven. 





He wonders why, distantly. If he’s dead, why would this be the afterlife? He thinks fleetingly about a debate he had with Nancy one (though nobody could really 

debate 

with Nancy), about how heaven wasn’t real, how she’d said that people who ‘saw the light’ had all just experienced some trick of their dying brain chemistry. 





Maybe that was this. 





It doesn’t really matter, because Steve feels himself grow detached, falling back into the footfalls he’d practiced to be quiet back then, as the Harringtons liked their son to be seen, not heard; though sometimes the first wasn’t applicable, either. 





Steve Harrington is seven years old. It is the week before Christmas, and Steve Harrington is seven years old, Steve Harrington is home alone for the first time. Steve Harrington is not very good at reading, or math, but he can run faster than most boys in his class, which is why Kelly and Jenny and Tiffany and Shannon all have crushes on him at the moment. 


Steve Harrington is seven years old, and he’s lost two of his baby teeth, one of which was wobbly, so his dad tied a string to it and the door handle, slamming it until it flew out in a bloody mess, because Harrington men don’t ever do things halfway. 





Steve Harrington is home alone, he’s seven years old, and he’s scared of the dark. Steve hasn’t slept properly since his parents left on their trip, because Steve is scared of the dark, and has never been on his own for this long before, and Steve is scared. Steve wants to come and live with Tommy H and his family, because Tommy H is also scared of the dark, and they bought him a nightlight instead of locking him in a cupboard for a little while. 





But Steve doesn’t know Tommy H’s landline number by heart, doesn’t really get how the phone works, and it is much, much too dark to try and walk to his house now.





Steve Harrington is seven years old when he falls down the stairs—it’s not the first time he’s done it, he crawled backwards as a baby. But this time Steve trips at the top of the stairs because he can’t keep his eyes open any longer, and his head hits the bottom step with a sickening 

crack, 

a crack so loud that for a moment he thinks he’s dead. Steve Harrington is seven when he blacks out worrying about the small pool of blood that empties itself from the head wound, staining his mother’s nice, fluffy carpets. 





Maybe that’s why they got rid of the carpets, Steve doesn’t really remember. What he does remember is trying to single-handedly care for the first, (not the last) and one of the worst concussions of his life. He remembers throwing up for days, struggling to stay awake, fighting to eat any of the pre-made sandwiches his mother had made with numbers stuck to the white sliced bread so he wouldn’t eat them all in one go. 





He remembers crying on that same step that almost killed him when his parents got home on Christmas Eve, screaming about the sick stains, blood stains, but did not so much as tut over the large dip in the side of his head, one Steve can still find with his fingertips if he studies his scalp for long enough.





He remembers forcing himself not to cry when his dad took the Christmas bike wrapped up for little Steve apart piece by piece, scattering it across their garage. Remembers spending Christmas Day trying to rebuild it, believing he had, and trying to ride it to Tommy H’s house, only to discover that mechanics would never really be his thing when the wheel came off after a few pedals, and he still managed to break his little wrist. 





But that’s not quite how it goes this time. Seven year old Steve Harrington lies in his halo of sticky, hot blood at the bottom of the stairs, and is convinced that he’s dying. Only this time, the front door opens, and a girl, one much taller and older than him, stands there, a gentle stream of blood dripping from her nose.
